availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Louisville, Kentucky, attorney. Fayette County, Kentucky, native. Son of Edmund Bullock and Elizabeth Fontaine Bullock. Graduated from Transylvania University in Lexington, Kentucky, in 1824. Married to Mary Bullock. Father of William F. Bullock, Jr., Pearce Bullock, Henry P. Bullock, and Wallace Bullock. Began practicing law in Louisville in 1828. Member of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from Louisville from 1838 to 1841. Trustee of the Kentucky School for the Blind. Appointed circuit judge of the Fifth Judicial District of Kentucky in 1846. Attorney in Louisville in 1860. Owned two enslaved people in Louisville in 1860. Employed Bridget Flanigan as a servant in Louisville in 1860.

bibl.p: Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville, Sixth Ward, p. 30; Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville, Sixth Ward, p. 2; W. H. Perrin, J. H. Battle, and G. C. Kniffin, Kentucky: A History of the State, 8th ed. (Louisville and Chicago: F. A. Battey and Company, 1888), 753-56; Find A Grave, "Judge William Fontaine Bullock (1807-1889)," Memorial #92046669, https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=92046669&ref=acom (accessed June, 29, 2017).
